comments.html:
In the VoIP world I found it much easier to work with FQDNs instead of IP addresses specially when coupled with DNS SRV records. Why I waited so long, when it was really so simple? I attribute it to fear of change, or fear of having to troubleshoot a new call flow. Using DNS will also help with geographic redundancy. VoIP still has one major issue with dynamic ports for media channels.
But I agree with the post, I guess if we needed 1 simple talking point it is "leverage DNS".
comments.name: DourCdn

comments.html:
Static TCP/UDP port number is a must, otherwise you run into firewalling problems (you can filter static port with ACLs).

IP address should be as static as possible (but not more than that ;), otherwise someone might start feeling the urge to negotiate it via some weird RPC protocol.

Probably need to reword it. How about "application external entry point WITHIN ONE AVAILABILITY ZONE" ...
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
How about trying to make the applications as OPEN and PORTABLE as possible?
Regarding the firewall issues, you could use the same process to discover port numbers as applications should, i.e ... DNS(Sec)!
I'm not sure if it's possible with the security products which are available right now on the market, but it would be so much simpler to allow/ban applications (with their port numbers dynamically discovered through DNS) on Firewalls instead of manually configuring their port numbers inside ACLs or any other tools...
Regarding the IP address, the application SHOULD NOT know anything about it; if it needs it, there are APIs that can easily return that dynamic information from lower IPv4/IPv6 layers.
As a general rule, applications and network/transport layers SHOULD always be decoupled.

comments.html: I suppose Ivan meant in his first statement: "An application’s external entry point SHOULD NOT be defined by a static IP address and a static TCP/UDP port number(s)", otherwise using DNS A and SRV records would be pointless.
